item.description:
Report E-2024040334

Identified by scraper @ 2024-04-17T15:16:09+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-04-13
  • City: HENDERSON
  • State: CO
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS FREIGHT, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO Logistics contacted ERTS regarding one bottle of Rooto Professional Liquid Drain Opener leaking onto the trailer floor as a result of improper loading / inadequate preparation for transportation. A Contractor was dispatched and neutralized the release along with the damaged product using soda ash. The spill was cleaned-up with oil-dry. Two 15-gallon DF’s were generated for waste disposal containing the neutralized product, spent absorbents, and PPE. No storm-drains, waterways, or soil were impacted by this incident.

item.description:

Identified by scraper @ 2024-04-17T15:16:09+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-04-11
  • City: DORAL BRANCH
  • State: FL
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: AT THE UPS AIR CARGO FACILITY IN MIAMI, FLORIDA, CONTENTS OF A BLACK SHRINK WRAPPED SKID WAS INSPECTED PRIOR TO AIR MOVEMENT TO PANAMA. REMOVAL OF SHRINK-WRAPPING REVEALS MULTIPLE BOXES WITH UN3481 LITHIUM-ION BATTERY MARKS. THERE ARE NO DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS OR LABELS ON THE OUTER BLACK SHRINK-WRAPPING. THE SIGNED AIR WAYBILL OFFERED WITH SHIPMENT DOES NOT INDICATE LITHIUM ION BATTERIES IN COMPLIANCE WITH SECTION II OF PI 967.

item.title: Report X-2024040652
item.description:
Report X-2024040652

Identified by scraper @ 2024-04-17T15:16:09+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-04-08
  • City: CAROL STREAM
  • State: IL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: SequenceEvent: Large fully regulated hazmat package containing 4 4L glass bottles of methanol. The hazmat was being loaded to a trailer when the bottom of the box opened and one of the glass bottles fell out, completely breaking the bottle and spilling all of liquid. The bottom of the box looked to be glued but it loosened and caused to open when handling and moving box around. Other 3 hazmat glass bottles were undamaged. DescribePack: The box opened up from the bottom due to box possibly not having enough glue or glue not working properly. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Hazmat broken pieces were cleaned very carefully and all the liquid it spilled was cleaned with absorbent pads. The broken hazmat and the cleaning gear was placed inside a hazmat bag inside a plastic bin.

item.title: Report X-2024040645
item.description:
Report X-2024040645

Identified by scraper @ 2024-04-17T15:16:09+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-04-08
  • City: HOLBROOK
  • State: NY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: SequenceEvent: The box was unloaded off the trailer. Then the box was transported to the van that was to deliver the box. An hour later, the driver of the van saw the box was leaking white small granules. The driver called a manager who came over to the van with gloves, broom, dustpan and a red hazmat plastic container. The manager put the box inside the red hazmat plastic container and swept up any granules that came out of the box. He then gently put the granules inside the box. The box was then transported to the hazmat cage by the Ops Admin. DescribePack: The bottom of the plastic bucket had a dent on the corner. The dent was about 3" long. The bottom of the plastic bucket has a crack going along the outside seem about 8 inches long. Upon inspection saw underneath this plastic bottom was another plastic bottom. This inside plastic bottom was cracked in several places. The cracks ranged from 7 inches to 3 inches. I could see the product had leaked out of these cracks and the very outside crack. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: The box was turned upside down and placed inside a red plastic hazmat container. The leakage of the product stopped since the cracks were on the bottom of the plastic bucket that was inside the box.

Identified by scraper @ 2024-04-17T15:16:09+00:00

  • City: ELGIN
  • State: NE
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On April 4, 2024, one (1) 275-gallon tote of corrosive liquid was punctured by a forklift and released approximately 115-gallons of product to the trailer interior and pavement beneath. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from HazChem Environmental (HCE) to remediate the impacted site. HCE personnel deployed granular absorbents to the impacted roadway/trailer interior and swept them in with hand tools. HCE utilized an additional tote to complete a gravity feed from the impacted 275-gallon tote. All spent absorbents, absorbent pads and collected waste were collected and containerized into six (6) 55-gallon metal drums and PPE was containerized into a separate 55-gallon open top poly drum. All were labeled and set aside for terminal disposal.

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: SequenceEvent: QA was made aware that there was leaking hazmat on the ground. QA was told that the driver had the package on their truck from the previous day and that when he opened up his side door the package fell out of his truck and onto the ground. The package was put into a plastic lined bin. QA stopped the continued downhill movement of the liquid with absorbent pads. The liquid was tested and came up acidic. Neutralizer was put onto the spill until it came up as non-acidic. Loose particulate was then placed on the spill area to absorb the liquid. DescribePack: The cap was loose on one of the jugs. The cap fell off after the package fell out of the drivers truck. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Neutralizer was used to negate the acid in the liquid. Loose particulate was placed on the spill.

item.title: Report X-2024040525
item.description:
Report X-2024040525

Identified by scraper @ 2024-04-17T15:16:09+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-04-03
  • City: SANTA MARIA
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: SequenceEvent: The package came back to the end of the vanline and it was placed on the floor flush to the back wall of the vanline. The cause of the damage is unknown but the outer box did not indicate it was a hazmat. Inner box had all the necessary markings. DescribePack: upon discovery the outer box had a wet spot on it like it had been dripped down internally. At the time I did not know it was a hazmat as the outer box did not have any markings on it to indicate that it was a hazmat. The inner box had a large wet spot on the top and partially down both sides of the inner box. Other than that there wasnt any other kind of damage to the outer or inner box. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Once I discovered it was a hazmat I had to run to the sink and thoroughly wash my hands as I had touched the wet part of the box. When I returned I put on nitrile gloves, grabbed a hazmat bag, and put the damaged package into a red lined bin. I then used some absorbent pads to soak up and wipe down the surface area where the box had been located.

item.title: Report X-2024040463
item.description:
Report X-2024040463

Identified by scraper @ 2024-04-17T15:16:09+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-04-01
  • City: DURHAM
  • State: NC
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: SequenceEvent: Package came off of truck in Unload notably wet, was placed into lined tote immediately and moved to safe area. Unable to determine if this occurred when initially loaded to trailer or during transit to our station. Upon opening outer packaging found one of four 4L bottles of water (non-hazardous) had somehow broken during shipping causing water to release inside package and eventually seep out as well. DescribePack: There were corrugated moldings around each of the four bottles to help protect during shipping but evidently was not enough to keep one bottle from getting broken. When that happened water leaked out inside, compromising structural integrity of inner, outer packaging and causing the box/moldings to tear and distort due to weight of 3 non-broken bottles. Bottle was already broken coming off of trailer so no knowledge of what directly caused damage to occur. DurationRel: 2 and MitigateEffect: Water had already leaked out due to bottle being broken completely. Cleaned up all wet areas in trailer and unload to re-establish safe working environment. Thankfully as stated through this report, the box was labeled as a Hazmat but did not contain any hazardous contents. Not sure if it was a mix-up by shipper when assigning labels to packages or what cause was, but no hazardous contents were in package or leaked out.

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: SequenceEvent: WHILE THE PACKAGE HANDLER WAS UNLOADING THE TRAILER, THEY NOTICED THIS PACKAGE WAS WET AND LEAKING. THEY INFORMED THEIR MANAGER OF THE SITUATION AND THEY IN TURN INFORMED QA OF THE PROBLEM. QA GRABBED A TOTE LINED WITH A CLEAR, LARGE HAZMAT BAG AND FOLD ABSORB. THEY RUSHED OVER TO THE AREA AND PLACED THE PACKAGE IN THE TOTE. ONCE THE AREA WAS SECURE, THEY BROUGHT THE PACKAGE BACK TO QA AND USED A PH STRIP ON THE PACKAGE AND NOTICED IT WAS HAZARDOUS AND PLACED IN THE HAZMAT PROCESSING CAGE. DescribePack: THE PACKAGE WAS PLACED ON ITS SIDE FOR SHIPPING. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: THE PACKAGE WAS PLACED IN A TOTE WITH A LINED HAZMAT BAG AND A PH STRIP WAS USED TO DETERMINE TO SEE IF IT WAS HAZARDOUS. ONCE IT WAS DISCOVERED IT WAS, THE PACKAGE WAS PLACED IN THE HAZMAT CAGE FOR FURTHER PROCESSING.

item.title: Report X-2024040692
item.description:
Report X-2024040692

Identified by scraper @ 2024-04-16T18:13:46+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-04-09
  • City: BARRINGTON
  • State: NJ
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: SequenceEvent: DURING THE UNLOAD PROCESS THE MANAGER NOTICED THAT THERE WAS PRODUCT LEAKING OUT FROM THE BOTTOM OF THE BOX AND ALSO NOTICED THAT THE BOTTOM CLOSURE OF THE BOX WAS OPEN AS WELL. THE MANAGER IMMEDIATELY TOOK THE PACLAGE OVER TO THE HAZMAT CAGE TO SECURE AND VENTILATE IT PROPERLY. I WAS THEN CALLED OVER TO REPACK THE PRODUCT INTO A YELLOW SALVAGE DRUM. INSIDE THE BOX THERE WAS A WHITE DRUM THAT HAD THE BOTTOM TORN OFF/DAMAGED WHICH THEN CAUSED APPROXIMATELY 1 POUND OF GRANULAR TO LEAK OUT OF THE BOX/DRUM. I REPACKED THE DAMAGED ITEM INTO THE SALVAGE DRUM IN A TIMELY AND SAFE MANNER AND AM NOW AWAITING THE DISPOSITION FROM PGH. DescribePack: THE BOTTOM OF THE DRUM HAD BEEN TORN/DAMAGED AND LOOKED LIKE IT WAS COMING OFF. BECAUSE OF THAT DAMAGED BOTTOM IT CAUSED APPROXIMATELY 1 POUND OF GRANULAR PRODUCT TO LEAK OUT. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: IMMEDIATELY TAKING THE BOX TO THE HAZMAT TO SECURE AND VENTILATE IT PROPERLY. I CAME OVER TO RAPACK THE PRODUCT IN A YELLOW SALVAGE DRUM IN A TIMELY AND SAFE MANNER.

item.description:

  • City: BESSEMER
  • State: AL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: SequenceEvent: Package had been unloaded from trailer and had gone overhead through conveyor system as normal. Package was loaded on van during sort. The driver of the van brought the now wet and leaking box to the Ops manager for the line and the QA for the line. Spillage was cleaned using oil dry and paper towels. Package and contents were placed in a smalls sortation bin on a spill pallet. QA completed DPR as normal. However, QA noticed corrosive labels on jugs and asked me for further clarification. Upon investigation of bottles and the SDS from the shipper's website for product, these were concluded to be undiluted jugs and needed special attention per SDS. DescribePack: One of the caps of the jug appears to have broken or come off in parts during handling, allowing all liquid contents to leak out. DurationRel: 2 and MitigateEffect: After consulting SDS, bottles, inner packing, and box were transferred to lined salvage been and transported to HMPA for further processing.

  • City: CHARLESTON

  • Description: 1. X-2024040656 SequenceEvent: The Hazmat was loaded on a van and before dispatch the driver informed the package of the leak. The package handler immediately notified QA given the close proximity to the QA cage. QA notified management and responded to the spill. The damage packages were removed and placed in lined hazmat totes. The leak was contained and the spilled liquid was neutralized. DescribePack: Loose caps. Bottles are in a spill containment bag(failed) used by the shipper so it is unsafe to do an inspection without the risk of spilling the amount still left in the bag. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Absorbent pads and neutralizer was used on the spilled liquid. The leaking hazmat was placed inside a line hazmat tote. 2. On the way to its destination to the shipper, it was discovered that the outer packaging was discolored , wet and a palpable chemical odor came from the box. . The package was placed into a plastic lined container for inspection. DescribePack: Both of the inner cans were dented , and the one that spilled the most liquid had its cap completely separated from the body. The hazmat is being processed properly after the manager notified QA about it. It was placed in a red tote and moved the hazmat area. item.description:

  • City: ALBUQUERQUE

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: SequenceEvent: I feel that when the shipper sent out the package the caps were never closed correctly. Which led to the leaking in the package during transit. Because package was never opened or anything. But when I discovered the package, I just was giving it a look and it looked dried, but you can tell it was leaking for a few hours. So, I just got gloves and got the whole package and opened it up and saw caps were loose which caused the leaking. DescribePack: Loose caps and they were about 9 qts and 8.52 lts bottles. And the location of leaking came from top of bottle where the lid wasn't closed correctly. DurationRel: 6 and MitigateEffect: I believe in transit there was nothing they could do but bring it back to station. Where I quickly discovered package and handled the situation. So, it wouldn't have leaked anywhere else.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: DURING THE UNLOAD THE MANAGER NOTICED THE PACKAGE WAS WET AND THE BOTTOM CLOSURE WAS OPEN. THEY IMMEDIATELY TOOK PACKAGE OVER TO THE HAZMAT CAGE TO SECURE AND VENTILATE PROPERLY. I WAS THEN CALLED OVER TO REPACK PRODUCTS IN A TIMELY AND SAFE MANNER. IT WAS REPACKED INTO A YELLOW SALVAGE DRUM. APPROXIMATELY 3 GALLONS LEAKED OUT DUE TO A PUNCTURE IN THE SIDE WALL OF ONE BOTTLE AND ALSO A LOOSE CAP ON THE OTHER BOTTLE. WAITING FOR THE DISPOSITION FROM PGH. DescribePack: THERE IS A PUNCTURE ON THE SIDE WALL OF ONE OF THE BOTTLES WHICH CAUSED THE WHOLE TWO GALLONS TO LEAK FROM THAT BOTTLE AND ON THE OTHER BOTTLE THERE WAS A LOOSE CAP WHICH CAUSED ONLY 1 GALLON TO LEAK FROM THAT BOTTLE. A TOTAL OF 3 GALLONS LEAKED OUT ALL TOGETHER. DurationRel: 2 and MitigateEffect: IMMEDIATELY TAKING PACKAGE OVER TO THE HAZMAT CAGE TO SECURE AND VENTILATE IT AND THEN HAVING ME GO OVER RIGHT AWAY TO REPACK PRODUCTS INTO A YELLOW SALVAGE DRUM SAFELY AND PROPERLY.

DurationRel: 4 and MitigateEffect: The package was put in a hazmat bin and the remaining liquid was cleaned with the hazmat absorbent cloth.

item.title: Report X-2024040359
item.description:
Report X-2024040359

Identified by scraper @ 2024-04-16T18:13:46+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-28
  • City: DURHAM
  • State: NC
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: SequenceEvent: As package was being placed onto a tugger in the Unload to be taken out to the Van Lines, a package handler said they thought they smelled a strange scent coming from packages on the cart and alerted QA. QA detected the smell was coming from this package and noticed small amount of outer packaging appeared wet from something inside, despite no other packages on pallet being wet. Upon determination, package was placed in red, lined hazmat tote and transported to processing area. No other packages found to be affected and upon opening Hazmat package (outer packaging then internal packaging containing regulated contents) determined the internal leakage was very minimal at time, all confined within inner and outer packaging. DescribePack: A cap on one of the two regulated containers within the inner packaging came loose somehow, resulting in a small internal leak of contents inside inner packaging w/ some product eventually seeping into outer packaging as well; all leaking was determined to be confined within inner and outer packaging, none on other packages or employees. No punctures or other signs/causes of leakage on any containers in package. Amount of leakage overall was very minimal. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: The Unload team was quick to alert QA upon noticing the odor when package came off of trailer and on tugger cart. This enabled the responding QA to assess situation, place the hazmat in lined red tote, and get it moved from the sort to the hazmat processing area in a timely, safe, & efficient manner while being sure to follow necessary protocols and procedure. As such the release of product was confined to the package itself and outer spill/leakage was prevented.

item.description:

  • Incident Date: 2024-04-11
  • City: FOREST HILL
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal LFW experienced a UN3098 NIL 8 release from a 2.5-gallon poly jerrican. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 0.5 cups of product released to a 1.5’ x 3” area of the trailer floor. The remaining material in the jug released into the poly bag/absorbents the pail was contained too prior to the crew’s arrival. The empty damaged jug, poly bag, absorbent and sodium bicarb were placed into a 55-gallon vented poly drum. The trailer floor was cleaned and neutralized with sodium bicarb. The impacted oil dri, neutralizer, impacted pallet wood, and poly 5-gallon pail which held the absorbents were placed into a second 55-gallon vented poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 55-gallons of product released to a 36’ x 24’ area of the concrete dock floor due to a forklift puncture. The damaged drum was placed into an 85-gallon metal overpack. Absorbents were then worked into the impacted area. The impacted absorbents were collected into (4) 55-gallon metal drums. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 4500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Mechanical employee conducting an outbound inspection noticed the strong smell of sulfur in the area of SHPX 209817. He left the area and reported it. NS Haz Mat and contractor responded checked the car and found high S02 reading around the manway area. We could also hear a hissing from the manway. Tightening manway bolts did not stop leak. Manway was opened and found to have two (2) gaskets in place, one flat in the manway cover and one mounted on the manway nozzle. Both gaskets were removed and replaced with new one. Manway was secured and tested with meter. No detect. Car was release for transportation.

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On April 3, 2024, one (1) 55-gallon drum of UN3098 was damaged prior to arrival and released approximately 55-gallons of product to the trailer interior and further migrated to the asphalt. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Thin Line Environmental (TLE) to remediate the impacted site. Crews collected the damaged 55-gallon drum and placed it in a 95-gallon over-pack drum for disposal. TLE deployed soda ash to the impacted asphalt and trailer floor to neutralize the release. Crews utilized hand tools to collect all impacted soda ash from the asphalt and the trailer floor. All hydrogen peroxide and peroxyacetic acid impacted material was collected and containerized in one (1) 95-gallon drum and thirteen (13) 35-gallon drums and added to RLC waste stream for disposal.

Due to the corrosive nature ERTS determined a contractor's assistance would be required. Hepaco arrived on site and found the terminal had placed soda ash on the spill. They pH tested the area and cleaned the impacted area with absorbents. One (1) 55-gallon poly drum with the damaged bottles and spent absorbent were left on site.

item.title: Report X-2024040316
item.description:

Identified by scraper @ 2024-04-15T15:12:24+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-28
  • City: CONCORD
  • State: NC
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: SequenceEvent: Hazmat was found in Unload B by the unload manager. Package was brought back to QA hazmat cage for inspection. During the inspection it was found. One glass jug had its closure component broken off. This was the cause of the leakage. Taking a closer look the bottle neck had a small glass piece missing from the bottle, the glass piece looked as though it had broken off. This allowed the cap to lose and come off in transit. DescribePack: One glass jug had its closure component broken off. This was the cause of the leakage. Taking a closer look the bottle neck had a small glass piece missing from the bottle, the glass piece looked as though it had broken off. This allowed the cap to lose and come off in transit. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: No damage was done to other packages. The broken jug had its cap tightened back to the bottle and placed into a 20-gallon salvage drum to prevent vaper and further leakage.

item.title: Report X-2024040266
item.description:
Report X-2024040266

Identified by scraper @ 2024-04-15T15:12:24+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-26
  • City: HUMBOLDT
  • State: TN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: SequenceEvent: Packaged Handlers were unloading a van that had the Hazmat. The Hazmat was toppled over when found and was leaking some of the chloride inside (solid). Package Handlers contacted an Ops Manager and informed QA/Coordinator of the incident. We removed the packaged from the vehicle and put it in a bucket to keep spilling anymore of the contents inside the station. It was taken to the Hazmat cage where upon further inspection found that the Hazmat material was inside of a plastic cylinder (outer container is a cardboard box). While transferring the leaking Hazmat, it was found that the bottom of the cylinder had cracked and was leaking a massive amount of the chlorine. The box itself was already filled halfway with the leaking contents. Admins wore protective gloves and used the ventilation shaft to not inhale the "fumes" of the chloride. The Hazmat was placed in a Hazmat container and DPR/ISF were filled out. DescribePack: The packaged appeared to have been repacked as it has a new label and was missing the shipping documents and had lots of tape wrapped around the closures. Looking at the photos from previous stations before it's arrival to the current one, it was in a much nicer box with better taping/packaging. The bucket likely could have been dropped at some point during it's transport casuing the bottom portion to be cracked, or likely from moving around inside the box as it did not have any filling inside to prevent the contents from moving around. The driver also could have secured the package to stop it from sliding around on the floor, perhaps had it on one of the shelves. DurationRel: 4 and MitigateEffect: Hazmat was removed immediately from the van and into a bucket in order to take it to the hazmat cage.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On March 25, 2024, eight (8) 50-pound bags of potassium nitrate were damaged by unsecured freight and released approximately one-hundred pounds of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from HazChem Environmental (HCE) to remediate the impacted site. HCE personnel overpacked the damaged bags in one (1) 55-gallon drum. The crew then utilized hand tools and a vacuum unit to further remediate the site. All potassium nitrate-impacted materials were containerized in one (1) additional 55-gallon drum. Both waste drums were staged onsite for future disposal.

item.title: Report E-2024040209
item.description:
Report E-2024040209

Identified by scraper @ 2024-04-15T15:12:24+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-21
  • City: AVINGER
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: CREEDENCE, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 143782
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: The driver of the vehicle was driving at approximately 60 mph when he felt a drop on the backend of the vehicle. At that time, the driver lost control of the vehicle and began to fishtail and then the vehicle rolled onto its top. A witness to the incident informed the driver that he had lost his back passenger wheels off the truck in transit and this caused the loss of control. It was determined that the wheel studs had completely broken off causing this to happen. The wreck and rollover are what caused the damage to the packaging of the chemicals. The duration of the release was approximately 45 minutes. Creedence immediately contacted an emergency response hazmat clean up crew and got them to the location of the incident. They immediately began containing the spill from spreading and cleaning what had been spilt. Creedence notified the National Response Center of the spill and TCEQ was on site directing the clean up the following day.

  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: SequenceEvent: PACKAGE WAS UNLOADED FROM TRAILER. WHEN MOVING THE PACKAGE FOR PROPER TRANSPORTATION TO VAN LINE, THE LEAKAGE WAS NOTED. THE AREA WAS CLEARED, PPE ALONG WITH NEUTRALIZER WAS RETRIEVED. NEUTRALIZER WAS APPLIED TO THE SPILL. BAY DOORS WERE OPENED TO ALLOW FOR ADDITIONAL AIR FLOW. DescribePack: DUE TO THE NATURE OF THE ITEM/SPILL, IT WAS NOT CLEAR AS TO THE EXACT INNER PACKAGE FAILURE. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: RED TOTES PRE-LINED WITH HAZMAT BAGS WERE USED TO PLACE IMPACTED BOXES INTO, WHICH STEMMED THE LEAKAGE AND REDUCED ADDITIONAL VAPOR DISPERSION. IN ADDITION, CHEMICAL NEUTRALIZER WAS APPLIED TO THE SPILL.

DurationRel: 2 and MitigateEffect: placed bottle in upright position

item.title: Report E-2024040289
item.description:
Report E-2024040289

Identified by scraper @ 2024-04-15T15:12:24+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-12
  • City: ORANGE
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: RANGER LANDSTAR INC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 41500
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: On March 12, 2024 at 1421 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Landstar personnel in Orange, Texas regarding the release of approximately (225) gallons of FERRIC SULFATE SOLUTION, Corrosive Liquid, Acidic, Inorganic, n.o.s. (UN3264, 8, III). Contractors were dispatched to the site to perform all onsite clean-up activities. Upon arrival, contractors investigated and confirmed the release was caused by a load shift due to a hard brake and was contained to the trailer floor and a 100ft x 6ft area of asphalt trailing behind the unit. Contractors neutralized the release then used absorbents and the proper PPE to clean the release. Contractors were able to transfer the remaining product in the damaged tote to a new tote without complication. All waste generated from addressing this release was containerized in (7) 55-gallon DF’s, which was then taken offsite by contractors for proper disposal. **The NRC report has the city of Beaumont (which the spill took place in Orange City), this 5800 report was completed to match the NRC report for fluidity**

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal LSL experienced a UN3082 Zinc Sulfate Solution 33 - 36% release from a 275-gallon poly tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 50-gallons of product released to a 10’ x 30’ area of the concrete dock floor due to a forklift puncture. The material was transferred from the damaged tote into a new one. Absorbents were then deployed and worked into the impacted area. The damaged tote was cut up and containerized along with all impacted absorbents into (3) 55-gallon poly drums. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • City: SIOUX FALLS

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO-XSO contacted ERTS regarding a punctured tote as a result of improper loading. The puncture resulted in a 12-ounce release of ScaleBreak onto the wooden trailer floor and the concrete dock floor. The trailer floor was impacted in a 4’x4’ area and the dock floor was impacted in an area of 4’x4’. A Contractor performed a tote transfer and cleaned-up the release. The damaged tote was cut-up and containerized for waste disposal along with the impacted oil dry, rags, and PPE. No storm-drains, waterways, or soil were impacted.

The accompanying safety data sheet identified the contents as "Quik-Foam HP" and classified the shubstance as a flammable liquid. The package was not prepared in accourdance with IATA regulations, missing the markings, labeling. packaging. and paperwork and is being held, pending an FAA investigation.

  • Description: WE ORIGINALLY RECEIVED THIS SHIPMENT ON 10MAR ON ORIG AWB 7065-2470 AND REFUSED DUE TO NO IAC PPWK AND FUEL SMELL ADVISED THAT THEY NEED TO CLEAN. RETURNED 11MAR AND AS ACCT CHARGES DENIED DUE TO OVERLIMIT. NEW AWB 7125 5413 WAS TENDERED ON 12MAR AND AFTER ACCEPTANCE DUE TO ITEMS SHRINK WRAPPED WE WERE PHYSICAL SCREENING AND DISCOVERED 10 FUEL BOTTLES AND ENTIRE PIECE WITH STRONG FUEL SMELL. SHIPMENT WAS TENDERED AS MACHINE PTS BUT ACTUALLY WAS CAMPING GEAR AND SNOW SKIES. CTCD THE SHIPPER AND STATED THAT THEY NEED TO TRANSPORTED BY GROUND.

item.title: Report E-2024040206
item.description:
Report E-2024040206

Identified by scraper @ 2024-04-11T15:11:27+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-04-08
  • City: LORDSTOWN
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 9500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XAY experienced a UN2922 Nalcon 7634 release from 275-gallon poly tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 100-gallons of product released to 60' x 20' area of the concrete dock and a 40' x 15' area of the asphalt parking lot due to a forklift puncture. The material was transferred from the damaged tote into a new one. Absorbents were then deployed and worked into the impacted area to clean the release. All impacted absorbents were containerized into (8) 55-gallon poly drums. The damaged tote was then cut up and containerized along with impacted absorbents and PPE into a cubic yard box. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • City: PERRYSBURG

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 9000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO-XTM contacted ERTS regarding a punctured leaking 5-gallon PAIL containing Endurastrip. The PAIL was punctured by a Forklift. The PAIL released all 5-gallons that impacted the wooden trailer floor and the concrete dock floor. The trailer floor had an impact area of 28’x5’. The dock floor had an impact area of 10’x1’. A Contractor cleaned up the release and repalletized the remaining, un-damaged product. Two drums of waste were generated for disposal. No storm-drains, waterways, or soil were impacted by this incident.

  • Description: On March 2, 2024, at 1424 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Roadrunner personnel in Los Angeles, California regarding regulatory reporting for the release of approximately 25 gallons of JP-8 (MIL-T-83133) FUEL, AVIATION, TURBINE ENGINE (UN1863, 3, III) from (1) 55-metal drum. The drum was found turned on its side and leaking upon arrival at the terminal, likely due to not being strapped in and secured properly. Terminal personnel conducted all clean up activities, and placed the leaking drum into an 85 gallon overpack.

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 4000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On April 2, 2024, one (1) 1-gallon pail of paint was crushed in transit and released approximately one (1) gallon of product to the top of the pail. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Lone Star Hazmat (LSH) to remediate the impacted site. Terminal personnel deployed absorbents to the release, swept them in with hand tools and containerized all spent absorbents in one (1) 30-gallon drum. LSH personnel overpacked the one (1) damaged pail in the same 30-gallon drum. All waste was staged onsite for future disposal.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: During sort operations at the MEMH facility a fiberboard box was found with signs of a release. The fiberboard box contained twenty smaller boxes and bubble wrap for dunnage. Each of the smaller boxes inside contained eight plastic bottles. The cap was loose on one of the bottles causing a release of its contents inside of the fiberboard box. All contents were placed into a steel salvage package and a new declaration will be obtained for movement.

item.description:

Identified by scraper @ 2024-04-11T15:11:27+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-04-02
  • City: CHICAGO
  • State: IL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 4000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On April 2, 2024, one (1) 1-gallon pail of paint was crushed and released approximately one (1) gallon of product to the loading dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from HazChem Environmental (HCE) to remediate the impacted site. HCE personnel utilized hand tools and absorbents to remediate the paint-impacted loading dock floor. All impacted material was collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum and staged on site for transport and disposal. HCE personnel repalletized the undamaged freight for shipping to its destination.

item.title: Report I-2024040041
item.description:
Report I-2024040041

Identified by scraper @ 2024-04-11T15:11:27+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-27
  • City: Narita
  • State: RI
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED AIRLINES HOLDINGS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Captain notified to SOC in NRT at 11:42L by ACARS. Thermal containment bag was used for 8A customer's IPAD, which was stuck on rail of her seat and broken. Upon arrival at NRT, CS SPVR retrieved the bag and IPAD was crushed. The customer agreed for us to confiscate at NRT due to no way to repair. We learned that she was not aware of dropping her IPAD at her seat rail, when she was reclining her seat, then she heard the sound of a crack which caused by breaking IPAD. No fire, no smoke and no heat were produced, but for safety, FA used the thermal containment bag and placed at designated location during flight. Passenger Information:, Name: Carol Pulliam Address: 167 N. Cleveland Ave#400 Oceanside, CA 92054 Phone: 951-543-8608 Email: myrtle007@sbcglobal.net

item.title: Report I-2024040037
item.description:
Report I-2024040037

Identified by scraper @ 2024-04-11T15:11:27+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-14
  • City: MIDDLETOWN
  • State: PA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: UNLOAD SUPERVISOR CALLED THE LEAKING PACKAGE IN QUESTION OUT ON THE RESPONDER CHANNEL RESPONDER PROPERLY CONTAINED AND CLEANED UP THE SPILLED AREA BEFORE TRANSPORTING PACKAGE BACK TO THE DMP ONCE AT THE DMR THE PACKAGE HAD NO OUTSIDE MARKINGS OR INDICATORS OF IT BEING A HAZARDOUS MATERIAL SO THE RESPONDER BEGAN PROCESS THE LEAKING PACKAGE. THE PACKAGE WAS NOT IN THE SYSTEM SO IT NEEDED TO BE GREEN BAGGED, DURING THE SOLIDIFICATION PROCESS, THE STRONG ODOR BECAME APPARENT. WHEN ASKED FOR INGREDIENTS, WE FOUND THE SDS OF THE PRODUCT(MARYKATE ON AND OFF HULL& BOTTOM CLEANER) IN QUESTION AND TURNED OUT TO BE A CLASS 8 CORROSIVE. WE IMMDIATELY STOPPED PROCESSING AND CALLED THE HAZMAT SUPPORT CENTER TO REPORT THE PACKAGE. PART VII- RECOMMENDATIONS/ACTIONS TAKEN TO PREVENT RECURRENCE

item.title: Report I-2024040043
item.description:
Report I-2024040043

Identified by scraper @ 2024-04-11T15:11:27+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-13
  • City: LONDON
  • State: RI
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED AIRLINES HOLDINGS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: From employee witness: During a cabin walk-through, I noticed a strong chemical smell. I could see a flight attendant speaking with a passenger in the aisle of the B zone cabin. They were standing next to a Polaris seat with a flashlight. I immediately asked the flight attendant what was happening, and where the smell was coming from. He showed me a broken cell phone belonging to 12A Norris Dodson. From what I was told, Mr. Dodson woke sometime prior and realized his phone was no longer on his person. He notified flight attendant and asked for help in retrieving it. In the process of searching for the phone, flight attendant activated the electronic seat controls. The phone was crushed by the mechanism and the lithium battery was punctured. When I arrived at the seat, the phone was hot to the touch. There was no smoke, or any other indicator of fire. But to be safe, between the chemical smell and the heat of the phone, I decided to place the phone in the thermal containment bag. The pilots were notified, and the information was sent to Ground staff.

item.title: Report I-2024040050
item.description:
Report I-2024040050

Identified by scraper @ 2024-04-11T15:11:27+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-07
  • City: Bridgeport
  • State: MI
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: MARTIN TRANSPORT, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 20712
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: Driver was traveling north bound on I-75 north of Flint, MI when he was pulled over by Michigan State Police at 16:15 ET for a lane restriction violation. Upon inspection of the tractor/trailer, the trooper detected a leak coming out from under the ss skin on the bottom of the trailer just in front of the rollover protection. A tub was placed underneath the leak to contain it until the cleanup crew from Michigan Spill Response arrived on scene. After a short period of time, the leak stopped and there was only residue on the trailer. At that time, the top of the trailer was visually inspected and right above the area of the leak, there was a 3" washout cap that had fresh residue in the area which indicated that it had leaked. When Michigan Spill Response arrived on scene, they went to the top of the trailer and determined that the front washout cap was loose. They removed the washout cap, inspected the gasket, and then secured the washout cap to the threaded connection. After replacing the cap, a surge test was conducted on site and the trailer showed no signs of of any further leakage. Michigan Spill Response cleaned the residue from the trailer and disposed of the product that was collected in the catch pan placed underneath the trailer. Once the residue was removed rom the trailer, the load continued on without further incident. L
